dn32:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
dn32:1.3: Then, late at night, the Four Great Kings—with large armies of spirits, centaurs, goblins, and dragons—set guards, troops, and wards at the four quarters and then, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak with their beauty, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
dn32:1.4: Before sitting down to one side, some spirits bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
dn32:2.1: Seated to one side, the Great King Vessavaṇa said to the Buddha,
dn32:2.2: “Sir, some high spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
dn32:2.4: Some middling spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
dn32:2.6: Some low spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
dn32:2.8: But mostly the spirits don’t have confidence in the Buddha.
dn32:2.10: Because the Buddha teaches them to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, lying, sexual misconduct, and drinking alcohol.
dn32:2.11: But mostly they don’t refrain from such things.
dn32:2.12: They don’t like that or approve of it.
dn32:2.13: Sir, there are disciples of the Buddha who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.
dn32:2.14: There dwell high spirits who have no confidence in the Buddha’s dispensation.
dn32:2.15: To give them confidence, may the Buddha please learn the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.”
dn32:3.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, on that occasion Great King Vessavaṇa recited the Āṭānāṭiya protection.
dn32:3.11: the brahmin who has lived the life!
dn32:3.18: Those in the world who are extinguished,
dn32:3.21: being great of heart and rid of naivety,
dn32:3.23: he who is helpful to gods and humans,
dn32:3.25: great of heart and rid of naivety.
dn32:4.5: and of whom, when sun has risen,
dn32:4.6: it is said to be the day—
dn32:4.9: That’s how they understand that lake there,
dn32:4.10: as an ocean of flowing waters.
dn32:4.11: From here that is the eastern quarter,
dn32:4.17: He delights in song and dance,
dn32:4.19: And he has many mighty sons
dn32:4.20: all of one name, so I’ve heard.
dn32:4.24: the Buddha, kinsman of the Sun,
dn32:4.26: the one great of heart and rid of naivety.
dn32:4.28: Homage to you, supreme among men!
dn32:4.31: We’ve been asked many a time,
dn32:4.32: ‘Do you bow to Gotama the victor?’
dn32:4.33: And so we ought to declare:
dn32:4.36: We bow to Gotama the awakened!’

dn32:5.27: And so we ought to declare:

dn32:6.6: it is said to be the night—
dn32:6.7: there is a deep lake in that place,

dn32:6.32: ‘Do you bow to Gotama the victor?’
dn32:6.33: And so we ought to declare:
dn32:6.36: We bow to Gotama the awakened!’
dn32:7.5: They do not sow the seed,
dn32:7.6: nor do they draw the plough.
dn32:7.9: free of powder or husk, pure,
dn32:7.11: After cooking in a tandoor oven,
dn32:7.13: Having prepared a cow with hooves uncloven,
dn32:7.14: they’re drawn about from place to place.
dn32:7.15: Having prepared a beast with hooves uncloven,
dn32:7.16: they’re drawn about from place to place.

dn32:7.30: And there are mansions and palanquins
dn32:7.31: for that great and glorious king.
dn32:7.39: and the royal capital named Āḷakamandā.
dn32:7.40: The Great King Kuvera, dear sir,
dn32:7.42: which is why the great king
dn32:7.44: These each individually inform the King:
dn32:7.48: There is a lake there too named Dharaṇī,
dn32:7.51: There is a hall there too named Sālavatī,
dn32:7.53: There the trees are ever in fruit,
dn32:7.54: with many different flocks of birds.
dn32:7.55: Peacocks and herons call out there,
dn32:7.60: and in the wood the woodpeckers.
dn32:7.61: The parrots and mynah cry out there,

dn32:7.86: ‘Do you bow to Gotama the victor?’
dn32:7.87: And so we ought to declare:
dn32:7.90: We bow to Gotama the awakened!’
dn32:8.1: This, dear sir, is the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
dn32:8.2: The monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen should learn this Āṭānāṭiya protection well and completely memorize it.
dn32:8.3: If anyone who does so is approached while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down by any non-human being with malicious intent—including males, females, boys, girls, ministers, counselors, and servants among the spirits, centaurs, goblins, and dragons—
dn32:8.4: that non-human will receive no homage or respect in any village or town.
dn32:8.5: And they will receive no ground or dwelling in my capital of Ālakamandā.
dn32:8.6: Nor will they get to go to the conference of the spirits.
dn32:8.7: In addition, the non-humans would not give or take them in marriage.
dn32:8.8: They’d heap personal abuse on them,
dn32:8.9: drop an empty bowl on their head,
dn32:8.10: and even split their head into seven pieces!
dn32:9.1: For there are, dear sir, non-humans who are fierce, cruel, and violent. They don’t obey the Great Kings or their men or their men’s men.
dn32:9.2: They’re said to be rebelling against the Great Kings.
dn32:9.3: They’re just like the bandits in the king of Magadha’s realm
dn32:9.4: who don’t obey the king, his men, or his men’s men,
dn32:9.5: and are said to be rebelling against the king.
dn32:9.8: If any non-human being with malicious intent—including males, females, boys, girls, ministers, counselors, and servants among the spirits, centaurs, goblins, and dragons—approaches a monk, nun, layman, or laywoman while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down,
dn32:9.9: one ought to yell, cry, and scream to the spirits, great spirits, generals, great generals:
dn32:9.10: ‘This spirit’s got me! This spirit’s entered me! This spirit’s annoying me! This spirit’s harassing me! This spirit’s hurting me! This spirit’s harming me! This spirit won’t let me go!’
dn32:10.1: To what spirits, great spirits, generals, great generals?
dn32:10.9: and the kings Nala and Janesabha,
dn32:11.1: This, dear sir, is the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
dn32:11.2: Well, now, dear sir, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”
dn32:11.3: “Please, Great Kings, go at your convenience.”
dn32:11.4: Then the Four Great Kings got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, before vanishing right there.
dn32:11.5: And before the other spirits present vanished, some bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
dn32:11.6: The first recitation section is finished.
dn32:12.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened, repeating all the verses spoken. Then he added:
dn32:13.4: The Āṭānāṭiya protection is beneficial, and is for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.”
dn32:13.5: That is what the Buddha said.
dn32:13.6: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
